channel.title: reading list on Dustan Kasten
channel.description: Recent content in reading list on Dustan Kasten

item.title: Books of 2020
item.description: Catching up on posting my annual reading lists. The List # Book Author Completed The Personal MBA Josh Kaufman February 9 The Last Wish Andrzej Sapkowski February 16 Making Work Visible Dominica DeGrandis February 21 Managing Humans Michael Lopp March 7 Managing Up Mary Abbajay March 14 Becoming Supernatural Dr. Joe Dispenza March 22 Leviathan Wakes James S.A.Corey April 5 Calibans War James S.A.Corey April 13 Hyperion Dan Simmons May 14 How to be an Antiracist Ibram X.

item.title: Books of 2019
item.description: Catching up on posting my annual reading lists. The List

item.title: Books of 2018
item.description: I’m posting this over a year late because I quit all forms of internet interactions. I’m not committing, but I’m thinking about writing to formulate my thoughts again so just pushing this up for posterity. The List I find it interesting to review what I gravitate towards after the fact to discover where my interests lie. Standout books for this year that I have added to my recommended reading list are as follows:

item.title: A Year Without Twitter
item.description: Two days ago I have been off of Twitter for a year. Life has been really good without it, but I also miss everyone in the React community whose ongoing relationship was primarily based around communication on Twitter. So I ask…do I come back? Or do I carry on with my life which has been really beautiful without the world-always-burning-down ethos of Twitter.

item.title: Books of 2016
item.description: Welp, it appears I have fallen off the reading list since having two kids. I did manage to sneak 12 books in yet this past year, but with a bit more fiction than years past. Apparently as I’ve entered 30 I appreciate entertainment just as much (or more than) learning. :) The List

item.title: Books of 2015
item.description: 2016 was not “the Year of the Book” for me. Instead I moved into a new house, changed companies, and my wife and I had had our second child. I also switched to Team Android, whilst my reading list was on my old iPhone, hence the reading list post in May. The List Highlights I would recommend Engage the Fox, The Worthing Saga, The (Honest) Truth About Dishonesty, and The Music of the Primes for all audiences.

item.title: Books of 2014
item.description: 2014 was my year off from reading. Well, I read the Game of Thrones series. Now I sit here waiting for George R.R. Martin to finish the Winds of Winter so I can move on with my life for a month before waiting another 7 years for the 7th installation in the series. But alas, here is the list: The List

item.title: Books of 2013
item.description: After accidentally reading 42 books in 2012, I had quietly set myself the goal of reaching 52 books in 2013. With a last minute book off of Lean Pub I pulled it off with 1 minute 12 seconds to spare. The List Highlights There are a few stand out books from this list. First and foremost, Thinking Fast and Slow by Daniel Kahneman is a great book. I am fascinated by how the human mind works and this was my grand introduction to psychology.

item.title: Books of 2012
item.description: In 2012, my voracious appetite for reading and learning had reached new heights. Without setting any direct goals for reading, I began the year consuming book upon book upon book and kept a running record of what I had read so at year’s end I could look back on it all and see what I had discovered. I inadvertently almost averaged a book a week and ended the year with 42.
